Thyme.ly

A "Smart" Productivity Manager

HIGHLIGHTS

Features you'll love

Simple

Thyme.ly was designed with you in mind. It comes integrated with macOS and ready to go right out the box.

Smart

Thyme.ly utilizes real-time machine learning to give you a personlized, customizable, "smart" productivity manager.

Secure

Thyme.ly stores your activity data on your local disk. We do not share, store, or send user-specific activity data.

FAQ

Frequently Asked Questions

How is Thyme.ly monitoring my activity?

Thyme.ly periodically gets data from your computer about your current active app name (like "Google Chrome" or "Sublime Text") and the activie app's window title (like "Github"). That's it! Thyme.ly then uses that data in ways that help you monitor your productivity.

How is Thyme.ly "learning" my activity perferences?

When you categorize an app (like Sublime Text or Microsoft Excel) as productive or distracting, Thyme.ly will remember this categorization. The next time you use that app, Thyme.ly will categorize this app automatically. Pretty soon, you won't have to manually categorize those sorts of apps very often.

When you categorize a website title as productive or distracting, Thyme.ly will also remember that categorization. It's no fun having to categorize every website you visit in order to get an accurate productivity score though! That's why Thyme.ly uses machine learning to help predict whether a website is productive or distracting based on its title. It does this by seeing how all users are categorizing websites and uses that to predict productivity. This means Thyme.ly will get smarter the more you use it!

Where is Thyme.ly storing my activity data?

Thyme.ly stores most of your activity data in a local database file in your own computer. This data is never sent to the cloud or seen by us.

When you categorize an activity as productive or distracting, this categorization is sent to the cloud database along with a user id. This data is necessary for the machine learning aspects of Thyme.ly (more on this below), because this data helps train the app to make more accurate predictions.

However, if you are uncomfortable with certain classifications being sent to the cloud, pressing "delete" on the activity card triggers its deletion from the database. Of course, you can pause the activity monitor at any time.

What technologies does Thyme.ly use?

Thyme.ly is essentially two apps in one! The Thyme.ly client uses React with Redux to render views. The client is also wrapped in Electron, an library developed by Github that allows developers to create cross-platform desktop apps using JavaScript. The client also uses a SQLite database for local storage.

The Thyme.ly server runs Node.js using the Express web framework. It uses a PostgreSQL database. The server also has a web worker that uses Puppeteer/Headless Chrome to bulk scrape productive and distracting website titles. Finally, the server's machine learning uses the Naive Bayes Classifier algorithm.
